sect2.title: Creating an action
sect2.para:
To create a new action, choose
Ctrl N
File New action .
A new action is inserted in the items list. The exact place where the action is inserted depends of the current sort order of the items list:

listitem.para: The new action is inserted just before the current action or menu.
This place will not change when you later modify the label of the action.
The new action is inserted at the correct place, regarding the default «sp;New Nautilus action&spraquo; label.
This place will be automatically changed, each time you modify the label of the action.

sect2.para: Properties of this new action are also displayed in right tabs.

note.para: In theitems list, the new action is displayed in italic characters. Italics are used as a reminder that the item has not yet been saved.

The new action is also displayed in red color in the items list. Red color is used as an indicator that the item is invalid, that is that the item cannot be candidate to be displayed in a &nautilus; context menu because some of its informations are missing or erroneous. Here, and though this newly inserted action has some suitable defaults, it lacks a command to be executed to be considered valid by &appname;

sect3.title: Where should appear the action ?
sect3.para: &nautilus; file-manager may display your custom action in different places, depending on you will request here, and if some item is currently selected.

sect4.title: Targeting the selection context menu
sect4.para: When Display item in selection context menu checkbox is activated, then your action will be candidate to be displayed in &nautilus; context menu, as long as at least one item is selected in the file-manager. Your action will so deal with currently selected item(s).

tip.para: When an action targets the selection context menu, and is actually displayed in &nautilus; context menu, then it is also displayed in the Edit menu.

sect4.para: This checkbox is activated by default.

When targeting the selection context menu, and in order to be actually displayed, all the conditions defined in your candidate action must be met by each item currently selected in the &nautilus; file-manager.

sect4.title: Targeting the location context menu
sect4.para: When Display item in location context menu checkbox is activated, then your action will be candidate to be displayed in &nautilus; context menu, when the file-manager selection will be empty. Your action will so deal with currently displayed location.

tip.para: When an action targets the location context menu, and is actually displayed in &nautilus; context menu, then it is also displayed in the File menu.

sect4.para: When targeting the location context menu, and in order to be actually displayed, all the conditions defined in your candidate action must be met by the location currently displayed in the &nautilus; file-manager.

sect4.title: Targeting the toolbar
sect4.para: When Display item in the toolbar checkbox is activated, then your action will be candidate to be displayed in &nautilus; toolbar.

Actions displayed in the toolbar only deal with the location which is currently displayed in the file-manager, not with the items which may be currently selected (or not). In order to be displayed, all the conditions defined in your candidate action must so be met by the current location.

sect4.title: Notes
sect4.para: An action may target both the selection context menu, the location context menu and the toolbar, or one or more among these. If no target is defined, i.e. if the three checkboxes are unchecked, then your action will never be displayed.

sect3.title: How the action will it appear ?

sect4.title: If your action targets a menu
sect4.para: Whether your action targets the selection context menu or the location context menu, and both in &nautilus; context menus that in File or Edit menus, your action will be displayed as

listitem.para: the Context label as a label,

The label is a mandatory property of your action. If it happens to be empty, then your action will be considered as invalid by &prodname;, and will never be candidate to be displayed in the file-manager context menus.
the Icon,
associated with the Tooltip.

note.para: Depending of the exact configuration of your desktop environment, the icon may or may not be displayed in front of the label in the menu.

tip.para: You may embed some parameters in the label, the icon name of the tooltip. These parameters will be dynamically substituted at runtime with values which will depend of currently selected item(s).

sect4.title: If your action targets the toolbar
sect4.para: In the toolbar, your action will be displayed as

listitem.para: the Toolbar label as a label,

tip.para: The toolbar label defaults to the same label than those used in menus. By unchecking the Use same label for icon in the toolbar checkbox, then you can define a label specific to the toolbar, usually shorter those defined for the menus.

listitem.para: the Icon,
associated with the Tooltip.

note.para: Depending of the exact configuration of your desktop environment, the toolbar label may or may not be displayed in front of the icon in the toolbar.

tip.para: You may embed some parameters in the toolbar label, the icon name of the tooltip. These parameters will be dynamically substituted at runtime with values which will depend of currently selected item(s).

sect4.title: Choosing an icon
sect4.para: You have two ways of choosing the icon associated to your action.

listitem.para: Click on the dropdown list to select an icon among standard themed icons of your desktop environment.
Click on the Browse button to search for an image in the filesystem.

sect3.title: When the action will it be displayed ?
sect3.para: Whether your action is actually displayed in &nautilus; file-manager context menus and toolbar depends of the conditions you will define for it.
All defined conditions must be satisfied by the current file-manager selection (resp. location) in order your action be displayed.

sect4.title: Basenames

textobject.phrase: Shows the tab which lets you define basename-based conditions.

sect4.para: You may define that your action will only appear depending on the basenames of the items currently selected in the file-manager. You may define that each item of the selection must meet some sort of condition; and you may simultaneously decide that none of the selected item(s) can have some other sort of basename.
Defining a new basename-based condition involves only two simple steps.

listitem.para:
Press Insert or click on
button to insert a new condition filter

tip.para: A condition may use «sp;*&spraquo; or «sp;?&spraquo; wildcard characters.

listitem.para: Click on the Must match one of or Must not match any of radio button in the same row to set a «sp;must have&spraquo; or «sp;must not have&spraquo; condition.

sect4.para: Depending of your target operating system, make sure that the Match case checkbox is activated (or not).

listitem.para: When activated, all filters are considered as case sensitive, which means that /my/file filename is considered distinct from My/File one.
This is the default behavior on Unix-like systems.
When disactivated, filters are considered as case insensitive, which means that /my/file and My/File filenames are considered the same name.
This is most probably what you want if you target some sort of &windows; system.

sect4.para: When the action is examined to see if it should be displayed, the basename of each currently selected item is compared to the list of these basename-based conditions for this action.
By default, the basename-based condition is just one «sp;must match *&spraquo; condition. This means that basenames are not considered as a relevant condition for the action.

sect4.title: Mimetypes

textobject.phrase: Shows the tab which lets you define mimetype-based conditions.

sect4.para: You may define that your action will only appear depending on the mimetypes of the items currently selected in the file-manager. You may define that each item of the selection must meet some sort of condition; and you may simultaneously decide that none of the selected item(s) can have some other sort of mimetype.
Defining a new mimetype-based condition involves only two simple steps.

listitem.para:
Press Insert or click on
button to insert a new condition filter
A mimetype must be defined as a group/subgroup group.
Some sort of wildcards are accepted.
The «sp;*/*&spraquo; literal matches all mimetypes. As a convenient shortcut, the «sp;*&spraquo; literal is also accepted for the same purpose.
A «sp;group/*&spraquo; string matches all subgroups of group mimetype.

note.para: The «sp;*/subgroup&spraquo; string is not accepted as a valid wildcard.

listitem.para: Click on the Must match one of or Must not match any of radio button in the same row to set a «sp;must have&spraquo; or «sp;must not have&spraquo; condition.

sect4.para: When the action is examined to see if it should be displayed, the mimetype of each currently selected item is compared to the list of these mimetype-based conditions for this action.
By default, the mimetype-based condition is just one «sp;must match */*&spraquo; condition. This means that mimetypes are not considered as a relevant condition for the action.

listitem.para: Matches all items.
Matches all regular files.
Matches only directories.

sect4.title: Folders

textobject.phrase: Shows the tab which lets you define folder-based conditions.

sect4.para: You may define that your action will only appear depending on the directory the items currently selected in the file-manager are located in. You may define that each item of the selection must be located in one hierarchy or in another; and you may simultaneously decide that none of the selected item(s) can be located in some other hierarchy.
Defining a new folder-based condition involves only two simple steps.

listitem.para:
Press Insert or click on
button to insert a new condition filter, or click on Browse to select a folder on the filesystem.
A folder-based condition must be understood as the specification of the hierarchy in which the currently examined item should (or should not) stay.

note.para: The «sp;*&spraquo; and «sp;?&spraquo; characters are accepted as wildcards at any level of the defined folder filter.

listitem.para: Click on the Must match one of or Must not match any of radio button in the same row to set a «sp;must have&spraquo; or «sp;must not have&spraquo; condition.

sect4.para: When the action is examined to see if it should be displayed, the location of each currently selected item is compared to the list of these folder-based conditions for this action.
By default, the folder-based condition is just one «sp;must match /&spraquo; condition. As / is always the top of an Unix-like filesystem, then all selected files always match this condition.

note.para: If you target a &windows; system, then this default value may not be what you actually want.

sect4.title: Schemes

textobject.phrase: Shows the tab which lets you define scheme-based conditions.

sect4.para: You may define that your action will only appear depending on the schemes of the URIs of the items currently selected in the file-manager. You may define that each item of the selection must have some scheme; and you may simultaneously decide that none of the selected item(s) may have some other scheme.
Defining a new scheme-based condition involves only two simple steps.

listitem.para:
Press Insert or click on
button to insert a new condition filter, or click on Common to select a scheme among these defined as default schemes in
Edit Preferences .
Scheme-based conditions only accept «sp;*&spraquo; wildcard, which stands for «sp;any scheme&spraquo;.
Click on the Must match one of or Must not match any of radio button in the same row to set a «sp;must have&spraquo; or «sp;must not have&spraquo; condition.

sect4.para: When the action is examined to see if it should be displayed, the scheme of the URI of each currently selected item is compared to the list of these scheme-based conditions for this action.
By default, the folder-based condition is just one «sp;must match *&spraquo; condition, which means that schemes are not relevant for this action.

sect4.title: Capabilities
sect4.para: Capabilities are some properties that a file may exhibit to the user.

textobject.phrase: Shows the list of managed capabilities.

sect4.para: But the Local capability, all others are dependant of the user who executes the command.

textobject.phrase: Shows the tab which lets you define capability-based conditions.

sect4.para: You may so decide that your action will appear, or not, depending on the capabilities of the selected item(s) vs. the current user.
Defining a new capability-based condition involves only two simple steps.

listitem.para:
Press Insert or click on
button to insert a new condition filter.
Click on the Must match one of or Must not match any of radio button in the same row to set a «sp;must have&spraquo; or «sp;must not have&spraquo; condition.

sect4.para: When the action is examined to see if it should be displayed, this list of capabilities that selected item(s) must match (or not) is compared to those exhibited to the user.
By default, the capability-based condition list is empty. This means that capabilities are not relevant for this action.

note.para: If you target a &windows; system, then this default value may not be what you actually want.

textobject.phrase: Shows the tab which lets you define environment-based conditions.

sect5.title: Selection count
sect5.para: You may define that your action will only appear if the current selection in the file-manager has some precise count.

example.title: A selection count use case
example.para: If your action consists in displaying the difference between two files, you may define here Count = (equal to) 2.

sect5.para: To define a selection count condition

listitem.para: Select in the dropdown list the operator you want apply to the selection count
Enter the reference count you wish.

sect5.para: The selection count defaults to Count > (strictly greater than) 0 which means that the action will be candidate to be displayed as soon as at least one item is selected in the file-manager.

sect5.title: Desktop environment
sect5.para: You may define that your action will only appear in some given desktop environments, or, contrarily, will not appear in some given desktop environments.
To define the desktop environment condition

listitem.para: First select the type of filter

simplelist.member: does your action should always appear, regarding of the desktop environment ?
does your action should also appear in some desktop environment(s) ?
does your action should never appeat in some desktop environment(s) ?

listitem.para: If your action does not should always appear, then select the relevant desktop environment(s) in the listbox in the right side.

sect5.para: The target desktop environment condition defaults to Always appear which means that the action will be candidate to be displayed regarding of the current desktop environment.

sect5.title: Presence of an executable
sect5.para: You may define that your action will only appear in some given file is present on the filesystem and is executable.
To define the relevant file, enter its full filename in the Appears if the file is executable entry box, or click on Browse to select a file on the filesystem.
Leave the field empty if this condition is not relevant for your action.

tip.para: You may embed some parameters in the searched filename or its options. These parameters will be dynamically substituted at runtime with values which will depend of currently selected item(s).

sect5.title: D-Bus-registered name
sect5.para: You may define that your action will only appear in some given name is registered on D-Bus system at runtime.
To define the relevant name, enter it in the Appears if the name is registered on D-Bus entry box.
Leave the field empty if this condition is not relevant for your action.

tip.para: You may embed some parameters in the searched name. These parameters will be dynamically substituted at runtime with values which will depend of currently selected item(s).

sect5.title: Customized condition
sect5.para: You may define that your action will only appear in some given command outputs a true string.
This lets you define your own customized condition filter, by writing a small script which outputs, or not, the true string when it is ran.
To define the command, enter it in the Appears if the command outputs "true" entry box.
Leave the field empty if this condition is not relevant for your action.

tip.para: You may embed some parameters in the executed filename or its options. These parameters will be dynamically substituted at runtime with values which will depend of currently selected item(s).

sect5.title: Running process
sect5.para: You may define that your action will only appear in some given binary is currently running.
To define the binary, enter its name in the Appears if the binary is running entry box, or click on Browse to select a file on the filesystem.

note.para: Even if you enter here the full filename of a binary, only its basename will be searched for in the processes list at runtime.

sect5.para: Leave the field empty if this condition is not relevant for your action.

tip.para: You may embed some parameters in the searched name. These parameters will be dynamically substituted at runtime with values which will depend of currently selected item(s).

sect3.title: What the action should it execute ?
sect3.para: You most probably want your action eventually ends up with executing something. As a matter of fact, having something to execute is one of the few conditions which are required in order an action be considered as valid.
Enter the command you wish to execute in the Path entry box. Or click on Browse to select a file on the filesystem.
Enter the parameters of your command in the Parameters entry box.
The Legend button has a toggling action: click once to display the Parameter Legend dialog box; click a second time to hide it.

textobject.phrase: Shows the list of available parameters.

note.para: That the Path and Parameters fields be separated is only a matter of making easier to set up the data.

If you do not use, by example, the Browse button, you may perfectly enter the path of the command along with its parameters in any of the Path or Parameters entry boxes (but not in both), as long as you take care of separating them by at least one space.

sect3.title: Where the action should it be executed ?
sect3.para: Your action may be executed in a particular working directory. You may specify it in the Command tab, in the Working directory entry box, or by clicking on Browse to select a folder on the filesystem.
The working directory defaults to %d, which runs the command in the base directory of the first selected item.

sect3.title: How the action should it be executed ?

textobject.phrase: Shows how to configure the execution mode of a command.

sect4.title: Specifying the execution mode
sect4.para: The execution mode of your command may be choosen between following values:

listitem.para: Starts the command as a standard graphical user interface.
Starts the preferred terminal of the desktop environment, and runs the command in it.
Makes use of a special feature of the file manager which may allow a terminal to be ran in it.
As &nautilus; does not have this feature, this option is strictly equivalent to Terminal option.
Starts the preferred terminal of the desktop environment, and runs the command in it. At end, standard streams (stdout, stderr) are collected and displayed.

sect4.para: The execution mode of a command defaults to Normal. That is, the command is executed without any particular pre- or post-work.

sect4.title: Specifying the startup notification
sect4.para: If the execution mode of the command is actually Normal, and if you know that the application will send a remove message with the DESKTOP_STARTUP_ID environment variable set, then check the Startup notify checkbox.

See the
Startup Notification Protocol Specification for more details.

sect4.title: Specifying the window class
sect4.para: If the execution mode of the command is actually Normal, and if you know that the application will map at least one window with a given class name, then enter that name into the Startup Window Manager class entry box.

See the
Startup Notification Protocol Specification for more details.

sect4.title: Specifying the owner of the execution
sect4.para: Enter in the Execute as user entry box the username or the UID of the user your command must be ran as.
If you do not enter anything in this field, then the command will be executed as the current user.
